\makeatletter
\newenvironment{kframe}{%
 \def\FrameCommand##1{\hskip\@totalleftmargin \hskip-\fboxsep
 \colorbox{shadecolor}{##1}\hskip-\fboxsep
     % There is no \@totalrightmargin, so:
     \hskip-\linewidth \hskip-\@totalleftmargin \hskip\columnwidth}%
 \MakeFramed {\advance\hsize-\width
   \@totalleftmargin\z@ \linewidth\hsize
   \@setminipage}}%
 {\par\unskip\endMakeFramed}
\makeatother

\end{center}



\subsection*{Problem 1}
\label{problem1}


\begin{knitrout}
\definecolor{shadecolor}{rgb}{.97, .97, .97}{\color{fgcolor}\begin{kframe}
\begin{flushleft}
\ttfamily\noindent
\hlfunctioncall{data}\hlkeyword{(}\hlsymbol{Howell1}\hlkeyword{)}\hspace*{\fill}\\
\hlstd{}\hlsymbol{d2}{\ }\hlassignement{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxlessthan}-}{\ }\hlsymbol{Howell1}\hlkeyword{[}\hlsymbol{Howell1}\hlkeyword{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxdollar}}\hlsymbol{age}{\ }\hlkeyword{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxgreaterthan}=}{\ }\hlnumber{18}\hlkeyword{,}{\ }\hlkeyword{]}\mbox{}
\normalfont
\end{flushleft}
\end{kframe}}
\end{knitrout}


Model the relationship between height $h_i$ and weight $w_i$ as
\[
h_i  \sim {\rm Normal}\left ( \mu_i, \sigma \right). 
\]

with $\mu_i = \alpha + \beta w_i$

Note that $h_i$ is column `height` and $w_i$ is column `weight` in the data frame `d2`. 

\begin{knitrout}
\definecolor{shadecolor}{rgb}{.97, .97, .97}{\color{fgcolor}\begin{kframe}
\begin{flushleft}
\ttfamily\noindent
\hlsymbol{mle.hw}{\ }\hlassignement{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxlessthan}-}{\ }\hlfunctioncall{mle2}\hlkeyword{(}\hlsymbol{height}{\ }\hlkeyword{\urltilda{}}{\ }\hlfunctioncall{dnorm}\hlkeyword{(}\hlargument{mean}{\ }\hlargument{=}{\ }\hlsymbol{alpha}{\ }\hlkeyword{+}{\ }\hlsymbol{beta}{\ }\hlkeyword{*}{\ }\hlsymbol{weight}\hlkeyword{,}\hspace*{\fill}\\

\end{knitrout}


A simple interpretation of the coefficients implies:

\begin{itemize}
  \item on average a child gains 27.2 units in height for each gain of 10 units in weight
  \item a child of zero weight is 58.23 units tall
\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{c}

Most concerned by the performance of the fit at low and high weights. 
In particular, the model underpredicts height at the upper end of the weight range, and overpredicts at lower end of the range.
I expect these poblems arise because the linear model cannot accommodate the biological reality of growth and development; the amount of energy (weight) allocated height may change over development. 
Further, height levels off at low weights.

To accommodate biological reality, I would use a model where growth has  non-linear relationship with weight.
Maybe a sinusoid: non-growth development early, then even develoment/height, then leveling off to maintenance.
Would like to keep intercept at zero though

One could also transform the data\dots 


\subsection*{Problem 3}

For the Howell dataset (n=544 individuals) we  model the relationship between height (cm) and the natural logarithm of weight (log-kg). 
\[\begin{split}h_i \sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\ \mu_i =\alpha+\beta \log(w_i),\end{split}\]
where $h_i$ is the height (in cm), and $w_i$ the weight (in kg), of individual i. 

We use the entire Howell1 data frame, all 544 rows, adults and non-adults. 

\subsubsection{(a)}

First, we fit model, using a quadratic approximation of the likelihood

\begin{knitrout}
\definecolor{shadecolor}{rgb}{.97, .97, .97}{\color{fgcolor}\begin{kframe}
\begin{flushleft}
\ttfamily\noindent
\hlsymbol{d}{\ }\hlassignement{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxlessthan}-}{\ }\hlsymbol{Howell1}\hspace*{\fill}\\
\hlstd{}\hlsymbol{d}\hlkeyword{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxdollar}}\hlsymbol{log.w}{\ }\hlassignement{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxlessthan}-}{\ }\hlfunctioncall{log}\hlkeyword{(}\hlsymbol{d}\hlkeyword{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxdollar}}\hlsymbol{weight}\hlkeyword{)}\hspace*{\fill}\\
\hlstd{}\hlsymbol{mle.loghw}{\ }\hlassignement{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxlessthan}-}{\ }\hlfunctioncall{mle2}\hlkeyword{(}\hlsymbol{height}{\ }\hlkeyword{\urltilda{}}{\ }\hlfunctioncall{dnorm}\hlkeyword{(}\hlargument{mean}{\ }\hlargument{=}{\ }\hlsymbol{alpha}{\ }\hlkeyword{+}{\ }\hlsymbol{beta}{\ }\hlkeyword{*}{\ }\hlsymbol{log.w}\hlkeyword{,}\hspace*{\fill}\\
\hlstd{}{\ }{\ }{\ }{\ }\hlargument{sd}{\ }\hlargument{=}{\ }\hlsymbol{sigma}\hlkeyword{)}\hlkeyword{,}{\ }\hlargument{data}{\ }\hlargument{=}{\ }\hlsymbol{d}\hlkeyword{,}{\ }\hlargument{start}{\ }\hlargument{=}{\ }\hlfunctioncall{list}\hlkeyword{(}\hlargument{alpha}{\ }\hlargument{=}{\ }\hlfunctioncall{mean}\hlkeyword{(}\hlsymbol{d}\hlkeyword{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxdollar}}\hlsymbol{height}\hlkeyword{)}\hlkeyword{,}{\ }\hlargument{beta}{\ }\hlargument{=}{\ }\hlnumber{0}\hlkeyword{,}\hspace*{\fill}\\
\hlstd{}{\ }{\ }{\ }{\ }\hlargument{sigma}{\ }\hlargument{=}{\ }\hlfunctioncall{sd}\hlkeyword{(}\hlsymbol{d}\hlkeyword{\usebox{\hlnormalsizeboxdollar}}\hlsymbol{height}\hlkeyword{)}\hlkeyword{)}\hlkeyword{)}\hspace*{\fill}\\
\hlstd{}\hlfunctioncall{precis}\hlkeyword{(}\hlsymbol{mle.loghw}\hlkeyword{)}\mbox{}
\normalfont
\end{flushleft}
\begin{verbatim}
##       Estimate Std. Error   2.5%  97.5%
## alpha  -23.823     1.3352 -26.44 -21.21
## beta    47.086     0.3826  46.34  47.84
## sigma    5.135     0.1557   4.83   5.44
\end{verbatim}
\end{kframe}}
\end{knitrout}


\subsubsection{(b)}

The model above is equivalent to

\[\begin{split}h_i \sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\ \mu_i =\alpha+\beta y_i\\ y_i = \log(w_i),\end{split}\]
where $h_i$ is the height (in cm), and $w_i$ the weight (in kg) and $y_i$ log weight (in log-kg), of individual $i$. 


Now we plot observations $h_i$ against $w_i$, as well as predicted means and 95\% HPDI for mean and predicted heights. 
In practice, this means plotting
\begin{itemize}
  \item $h_i$ against $\exp(y_i)$
  \item HPDIs computed for each $y_i$ against $\exp(y_i)$
\end{itemize}

For the mean prediction, however, we directly plot the curve
\[
\bar h = \alpha + \beta \log(w_i)
\]

    
\begin{knitrout}
\definecolor{shadecolor}{rgb}{.97, .97, .97}{\color{fgcolor}\begin{kframe}
